The Kennedy Conspiracy Paperback 19 Nov. 1998

by Anthony Summers (Author)
4.4 4.4 out of 5 stars 32 ratings
Sorry, there was a problem loading this page.Try again.
See all formats and editions
This vividly written probe of the Kennedy assassination, internationally acclaimed when first published, has been massively revised and updated. It includes the revelations resulting from recent releases of documents long withheld by US intelligence agencies. The author produces fresh information on the deceptions of the CIA; Oswald's trip to Mexico City shortly before the assassination; new information on nefarious activity in New Orleans; the botched autopsy of the President's body.

About the Author

Anthony Summers gained his degree at Oxford and joined the BBC. He covered the wars in Vietnam and the Middle East and smuggled cameras into the Soviet Union to interview Andrei Sakharov when he won the Nobel prize. Married with 2 sons, he now lives in Ireland in an ex-ferryman's cottage by the river Blackwater.

About the author

Follow authors to get new release updates, plus improved recommendations.

Anthony Summers

Brief content visible, double tap to read full content.
Full content visible, double tap to read brief content.

Anthony Summers is the bestselling author of eight nonfiction books. As a journalist with BBC television, he covered Vietnam, the Middle East, and major issues in the United States. His investigative books have ranged from the Kennedy to the Nixon years, and he recently produced what critics praised as the definitive account of the 9/11 attacks.

How customer reviews and ratings work

Customer Reviews, including Product Star Ratings, help customers to learn more about the product and decide whether it is the right product for them.

To calculate the overall star rating and percentage breakdown by star, we dont use a simple average. Instead, our system considers things like how recent a review is and if the reviewer bought the item on Amazon. It also analyses reviews to verify trustworthiness.

  • Mrs A Hunt
    5.0 out of 5 stars A REAL MUST READ
    Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 18 July 2007
    Verified Purchase
    I was born in 1963, was 5 months old when Kennedy was killed, but I remember when Martin Luther King and Robert Kennedy were killed. For some reason, the Kennedy assassination in Dallas has always been something I have been curious about.
    I've read many books about the assassination of JFK, a lot of them go on into great details about the ballistics/forensics which make the books boring and like wading through treacle. But with Anthony Summers, his writing is concise, he doesn't waste words, just tells the important, pertinent stuff, which makes it a far better book to read.
    obviously we will never know what really happened, but Anthony Summers investigative journalism makes this book easy to read and follow.
    No one escapes his microscopic overview of everyone concerned. We all know Kennedy was no saint, but who would want him dead? The list is endless, but what Summers does is covers each person in depth, giving the reader ammunition to make their own mind up
    We find out a lot more about Lee Harvey Oswald, how Jack Ruby, the CIA, Hoover, Police Department behaved, how they all fit into the puzzle, why was Oswald shot, who WAS Jack Ruby.
    This books makes the Warren Report look like the biggest work of fiction every printed, it shows how wrong they were, how they didn't look into every section of what happened, how the people they interviewed were the wrong people.
    Its not a laugh a minute, but it's an excellent read, and one which I feel should take it's place as the best overview of the Kennedy assassination written.

  • Patrick Collins
    4.0 out of 5 stars One of the better pro conspiracy books, but it does not convince
    Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 February 2007
    Verified Purchase
    Summers book is indeed one of the best pro conspiracy books on the assassination, in the sense that it is the better than many of its fellow pro conspiracy neighbours on the book shelf - and they number in the hundreds. Unfortunately most people only get to see one side of this debate and miss the few very fine and scholarly works that take the opposite view - that there was no conspiracy.

    If you are new to this subject the book will be convincing, however if you have armed yourself with the facts regarding the no conspiracy position you will find that it does not match the weight of evidence in favour of the lone assassin and therefore fails to convince. The general public has unknowingly suffered so much from such a vast wealth of utter none sense written on this case that what is historical fact and what is myth has become blurred into a single historical truth. If you want a well written reasonably argued book on the assassination, this is a good start for sure, but there is a lot of pure conjecture typical of the pro conspiracy lobby. Summers is a well respected expert on the case, but he is also rather commercially minded - after all this is what he presumably does for a living.

    An example of how a typical pro conspiracy argument seduces - and Summers is no exception goes like this - because of the condition of bullet 399 or the "magic bullet" it could not have caused all the non fatal wounds of Connally and Kennedy and even perhaps was a plant. Given that both men show reaction to being hit within a second of each other and given that Oswald's rifle could be fired once every 2.2 seconds, unless one bullet hit them both, there were two gunmen. But no consideration is given to the established fact that given the trajectory of the bullet through Connally being downwards at approx 22 degrees and slightly right to left from the rear, that the bullet had to have passes through Kennedy. Or put another way - Kennedy was in the way of Connally from the rear. Try it yourself - take two chairs, place the front one approx four inches to the left of the rear one and 2.5 feet apart and seat two people of similar size on each and raise the rear seat by 6 inches. Now consider the angles that you would have to fire from to hit your front man - Connally in the right upper back just in from the arm pit in order for the bullet to exit near his right nipple and end up in his left leg. Even that simple exercise gives you an idea that even though the single bullet theory is at first difficult to accept, it is more than likely true. The idea of planting a bullet whilst Connally was in surgery when it would not have been known how many bullets or fragments were going to be found, would have been stupid and in fact pointed more to a conspiracy than to a lone gunman had the bullets and ballistics subsequently not added up.

    This book does throw up some very good questions, however most of them can be answered. The book is now slightly outdated as in recent years given more incisive investigation and the use of technology for analysis of key areas, the pro conspiracy argument has been weakened somewhat. I would thoroughly recommend Mel Ayton's works on the assassination available on this site and although slightly presumptuous, Gerald Posner's "Case Closed" is probably the best foil for Summers. Recommended, but make sure you read both sides of the argument before forming your view.
    Read more
